trans-unit.source: With the members of the namespace, you can programmatically create grammars that comply with the W3C Speech Recognition Grammar Specification Version 1.0 (SRGS).
To create an SRGS grammar programmatically, you construct an empty <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument> instance and add instances of classes that represent SRGS elements.

The <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsItem>, <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsOneOf>, <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsRule>, <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsRuleRef>, <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsSemanticInterpretationTag>, and <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken> classes represent elements defined in the SRGS specification.

Some of the properties of the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument> class represent attributes in the SRGS specification, such as <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.Root%2A>, <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.Mode%2A>, <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.Culture%2A>, and <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.XmlBase%2A>.
See [SRGS Grammar XML](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/b888942f-637c-4243-b49f-1fbb6c12d9f1) for a reference to the elements and attributes of the SRGS specification as supported by System.Speech.

To add a grammar rule to a <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument>, use the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsRule.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsRule> class.
You can modify the text within an SRGS element using the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsText.Text%2A> property of a <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsText> instance.

With the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsSubset> class, you can optimize recognition of phrases in a grammar by specifying subsets of a complete phrase that will be allowed to constitute a match, and by selecting a matching mode from the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SubsetMatchingMode> enumeration.

See [Create Grammars Using SrgsGrammar](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/e4d9f96e-2241-4c39-b9e0-ac9ef4e9a906) in the [System Speech Programming Guide for .NET Framework 4.0](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/610116c7-3817-40ff-857b-5d41e8511043) for more information and examples.

You can also construct <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument> instances from existing SRGS-compliant XML grammar files, from an instance of <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsRule>, or from an instance of <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.GrammarBuilder>.

You can use the methods of the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsGrammarCompiler> class to prepare completed <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument> objects for consumption by a speech recognition engine.

Grammars created with members of the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar> namespace can be used by constructors of the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.Grammar> class to create <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.Grammar> objects.
